newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: SEOUL STOCKS END BARELY DOWN, EARLY GAINS ERASED.
newsitem.headline: SEOUL STOCKS END BARELY DOWN, EARLY GAINS ERASED.

text.p: Seoul stocks closed slightly lower on Thursday despite an early rise, ending three straight days of gains, brokers said.
They said selling pressure at the 750-point level triggered the relapse.
"Punters felt it was time for a little consolidation before it begins another march," said Choo Hee-yup of Dongwon Securities.
The composite stock index closed down 0.30 points to 745.35, with 34.2 million shares changing hands.
Brokers said the market could attempt a rebound on Friday.
"The consolidation could be short-lived. After all, the market has been consolidating for almost two months. Investors are now feeling a little more confident about the market," said Choo.
Shares of Dainong Corp and Midopa Department Store attracted much attention on the news that emergency funds had been supplied to the two troubled firms.
Dainong rose 190 won to its upper limit of 2,640 and Midopa gained 520 to its limit high of 7,020.
Brokers said Shin Hwa was the most heavily traded stock with 872,330 shares changing hands. It closed up 900 won to 24,500, after peaking at 25,400 in early morning.
Shin Hwa had previously plunged on rumours of cash-flow troubles, but it bounced back after the rumours were proven untrue, they said.
Hanwha Chemical was another actively traded stock with 322,270 shares changing hands.
Brokers said some investors accumulated the stock on talk of Hanwha's improved first-half results but some sold off, seeing it as an opportunity to take profits.
Hanwha Chemical lost 160 won to 6,740.
Brokers said Korean Air Lines shares managed to recover from a sharp loss on Wednesday following the crash of one of its jumbo jets in Guam. It gained 200 won to 15,500.
They said foreign investors bought up the shares on Thursday after dumping them on Wednesday.
The airliner's affiliate and insurer Oriental Fire and Marine Insurance ended flat at 21,500.
"Investors think the damage on Oriental Fire would be limited because the company was reinsured," said Choo of Dongwon.
Brokers said shares of struggling Kia Group units closed mixed after sharp falls in the last few days.
Kia Motors added 100 won to 13,000 and Asia Motors lost 120 to 4,500.
Kia Precision continued to benefit from a rumour that the nation's two carmakers Hyundai Motor and Daewoo Motor planned to buy stakes of the firm.
A group spokesman denied the speculation, but the stock ended at its upper limit of 9,790, up 720.
